metadata.case_name: Proprietors of lands in Rajasthan v. State of Rajasthan
metadata.case_number: Original Jurisdiction Petitions Nos. 50, 145, 149, 150, 188, 243, 261, 266 and 362 of 1955 and 205 of 1956

facts.text: Rajputana consisted of 18 principalities claiming sovereign status under British rule.
After independence, principalities integrated into United State of Rajasthan on May 5, 1949, via Covenant.
Under Article XI of Covenant, States united with common executive, legislature, judiciary as United State of Rajasthan.
Under Article VI(2) of Covenant, Rulers handed over rights, authorities, jurisdiction to new State.
Article X of Covenant vested legislative authority in Rajpramukh until Constitution framed and assented; Rajpramukh could promulgate Ordinances.
Article X modified: Until Legislative Assembly of Rajasthan duly constituted and summoned under Constitution of India.
Article 385 of Constitution of India: Until State Legislature constituted, pre-existing authority exercises legislative powers.
Legislative Assembly of Rajasthan constituted on March 29, 1952.
Rajpramukh promulgated Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Ordinance No. IX of 1949 on June 21, 1949.
Preamble of Ordinance: Check landholders' tendency to eject tenants, increase foodgrain production.
Section 4: No tenant liable to ejectment or dispossession while Ordinance in force.
Section 7: Reinstatement of tenants in occupation on April 1, 1948, subsequently dispossessed; extended by Amendment Act XVII of 1952 to later possessions.
Section 3(1): Comes into force at once, remains in force for two years unless extended by Rajpramukh by notification.
Notification June 14, 1951: Extended Ordinance for further two years from June 21, 1951.
Notification June 20, 1953: Extended Ordinance for one year from June 21, 1953.
Doubts on 1953 notification validity post-Legislative Assembly constitution; Rajpramukh issued Ordinance No. III of 1954 on February 15, 1954, substituting s.3 for five years operation.
Legislature repealed Ordinance III of 1954, enacted Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Amendment Act No. X of 1954, effective April 17, 1954; re-enacted s.3 for seven years.
Rajasthan Tenancy Act No. III of 1955 came into force October 15, 1955; pending petitions under Ordinance stayed by petitioners.
Petitions filed under Article 32 challenging Ordinance, notifications, Act X of 1954.

legal_issues.text: Whether notifications dated June 14, 1951, and June 20, 1953, are invalid as s.3 of Ordinance constitutes unconstitutional delegation of legislative power.
Whether notification dated June 20, 1953, invalid as Rajpramukh's legislative authority under Art.385 ended on March 29, 1952.
Whether Act No. X of 1954 invalid as it seeks to extend life of expired Ordinance No. IX of 1949.
Whether Ordinance repugnant to Article 14 of Constitution.
Whether Ordinance contravenes Article 19(1)(f) by imposing unreasonable restrictions on right to hold property.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notifications dated June 14, 1951, and June 20, 1953, bad as s.3 ultra vires, constituting delegation of legislative power.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Jatindra Nath Gupta v. Province of Bihar

petitioner_arguments.text: Notification June 20, 1953, bad as Legislature constituted March 29, 1952, ending Rajpramukh's authority under Art.385.
Act X of 1954 cannot revive dead Ordinance expired June 21, 1951 or 1953; amendment cannot operate on non-existent law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Jatindra Nath Gupta v. Province of Bihar (observations of Kania CJ, Mahajan J, Mukherjea J)

petitioner_arguments.text: Ordinance repugnant to Art.14; s.7(1) discriminates landlords with tenants on April 1, 1948; s.15 allows unfettered Government exemption.
Ordinance contravenes Art.19(1)(f); forces landowners to retain tenants, preventing self-cultivation.

court_reasoning.text: S.3 authorizing Rajpramukh to extend Ordinance life is conditional legislation, not delegation; valid per Queen v. Burah.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power to extend akin to power to bring into force at chosen time; legislature fixed law completely, executive decides continuance if conditions persist.

court_reasoning.text: Notification June 20, 1953, valid as exercise of power under valid s.3 of Ordinance, not independent legislation by Rajpramukh post-Art.385.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notification referable to Ordinance, not Rajpramukh's legislative competence.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide Act X reviving dead Ordinance as first two contentions fail; notifications valid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioners fail on delegation and Art.385 issues.

court_reasoning.text: Not repugnant to Art.14; date April 1, 1948, legislative choice; preamble guides s.15 exemptions; severable if bad.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Preamble recites policy against ejectments; courts cannot question legislative recital or date choice.

court_reasoning.text: Not violative of Art.19(1)(f); protects tenants from ejectment to ensure fixity of tenure for tillers; reasonable in public interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object to prevent ejectment after inducting tenant, not restrict self-cultivation; upheld in US precedents like Block v. Hirsh.

holdings.text: S.3 of Ordinance valid as conditional legislation permitting extension of duration.
Notification June 20, 1953, valid exercise under s.3, unaffected by end of Rajpramukh's legislative authority.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jatindra Nath Gupta v. Province of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Power to extend Act with modifications invalid as delegation; distinguished as here no modification power, pure extension.
Conditional legislation valid; legislature may leave time/manner of operation to executive.
Conditional legislation (bringing into force) valid; supports extension as analogous.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Narothamdas Jethabai
precedents_cited.relevance: Clarifies Jatindra Nath: invalidity due to modification power, not mere extension.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harishankar Bagla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Preamble guides discretionary power under Act, not unguided per Art.14.
Tenant protection laws valid, providing fixity of tenure.
Regulation of rates in public interest valid.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petitions; transitional legislative authority; equality and property rights challenged.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Ordinance No. IX of 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Core impugned law protecting tenants from ejectment; power to extend; reinstatement; exemptions.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Amendment Act No. X of 1954
Covenant for United State of Rajasthan
statutes_cited.relevance: Vested legislative authority in Rajpramukh pre-Constitution.

outcome.summary: Court upheld validity of Ordinance No. IX of 1949, notifications of 1951 and 1953, and Amendment Act X of 1954 against challenges of delegation, expiry, Art.14, and Art.19(1)(f); petitions fail on merits to enable disposal of pending tenant petitions.

key_quotes.text: "So long as the Ordinance is in force in any area of Rajasthan, no tenant shall be liable to ejectment or dispossession from the whole or a part of his holding in such area on any ground whatsoever."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core provision of Ordinance protecting tenants.

key_quotes.text: The power to extend the operation of the Act beyond the period mentioned in the Act prima facie is a legislative power.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Petitioners' reliance from Jatindra Nath, distinguished by court.

key_quotes.text: "Legislation, conditional on the use of particular powers, or on the exercise of a limited discretion, entrusted by the Legislature to persons in whom it places confidence, is no uncommon thing."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Queen v. Burah, upholding conditional legislation.
